item.title: Porting a Tiling Window Manager Extenstion to C++ (Bismuth): Part-2 (getting closest relative window)
item.description: Hi everyone! In this blog, I will be discussing the algorithm used in Bismuth to find the closest relative window to be focused for focusWindowByDirection event. If you haven’t read the previous blog, make sure to give it a read here. Recap from the previous blog Let’s start with a quick recap though, in the previous blog, we discussed: focusWindowByDirection requires the following information: direction (from the user) - can be one of: right, left, top/up, bottom/down.

item.title: Porting a Tiling Window Manager Extenstion to C++ (Bismuth): Part-1
item.description: Hi everyone! I understand it’s been a long time, and I’m so excited to be writing this blog today. In today’s blog, I wanted to talk about my journey (so far) on contributing to Bismuth (a KDE’s Tiling Window Manager Extension), mainly how and why I started, and where I am right now. The Story: Why KDE Plasma and Why Bismuth? For the last few months (close to a year), I’ve been using Pop OS (a linux distribution by System 76) which had this amazing automatic tiling window extension called pop-shell, and it was close to what I always needed:
